review_title: Disappointed that this is what college has become
pros:
Minimal work over the summer (after initial training)

Good pay if you have a masters degree outside of STEM

Can be rewarding if you have a good group of students

Teaching facilities are modern
cons:
They advertise 1330 hours of work per year because you have summers "off" but in reality its a full 2000 hours jammed into 38 weeks.

They claim your 35 hour work week is composed of 22 hours of teaching, 8 hours of office hours, and 5 hours of "other duties as assigned" (advising, referrals, mentoring, etc.). This leaves no time for class preparation, emails, and grading unless you can get that done during your office hours.

If you are adjunct faculty or if you pick up an additional class, you wont be paid for office hours, prep time, or grading. You are only paid for the time you are in class. This means you are paid for 48 hours of work to teach a 3 credit class that is 6 to 17 weeks long.

Difficult to take time off during the semester even if family emergencies occur.

Under normal schedules, all instructors are paid "equally" regardless of course load and number of students. This means you can end up working allot of hours while others work significantly less.

The union is kind of useless when it comes to fighting for employee rights. Wages were frozen this past year because of covid so no one got a raise, even if they were supposed to get one (like new employee raises). 

The teaching contracts were also made more one sided and instructors were forced to sign one sided work from home agreements.

Students can be... a handful. This shouldn't be an issue at a college level but it is. WITC does not have a standard when it comes to who they let in. They seem to think referrals and phone calls will fix serious behavior and maturity issues.

If you have realistic standards (some will call them high standards) you will have issues here. Basic things like due dates and cheating are a big issue that I feel WITC likes to ignore. 

I've had students rat out other students for cheating because its so common. This is especially common when due date policies are lax.

pros: Small classes, hands-on education, close industry ties, high student and employer satisfaction, high national rankings
cons: very trade oriented, very high teaching load, lack of student life, top-down management, lacking benefits compared to other educational institutions (no sabbatical, no tuition reimbursement, high cost of medical and retirement)
